New Guildhall Construction --------------------------
Information on construction of a guild hall is contained in the HELP CONSTRUCT section. This file will take you step-by-step through the steps required to construct a guild hall.
Guildhall location are subject to administrative approval. The admins will make a judgement call about the location based on its position relative to other guildhalls, hometowns and other zones, and overall map layout.

Guildhall Construction Rules and Notes
Last Modified: 1/21/99
This guide, written by Ski, should take you through the steps you need to perform when writing a guildhall for Magma. It is intended for use with the DE program, which can be obtained from the Basternae web page (http://basternae.org).
This guide assumes you know how to use the DE program. If you don't, you shouldn't be making the guildhall.
This guide is broken down into numerous sections. Type 'help construct1' for the first section.

1. Contacting the admins =========================
Before you start making the hall, you need to contact the Guildhall Admin. This administrator will give you certain pieces of information you need when making the zone. He should give you the following pieces of information:
1. Starting vnum for rooms, objs, and mobs. 2. Zone number 3. Your association number 4. A destination room number if you have a portal to a hometown.
You should tell the administrator where you would like the hall to go on the map. Guildhalls must be connected to one of the maps (either the overland map or the underdark map), they must be reached by a "normal" exit (ie no portals or teleports to the hall), the entrance to the hall must be at ground level (no flying guildhalls), and they cannot be located within 5 "spaces" of another guildhall. Goodie guilds cannot put halls in the underdark, and evils cannot put halls on the main overland continent.
Continued in 'help construct2'

2. Creating the Guildhall ==========================
The second step is to make a brand new zone using the de program. Easiest way to do this is just to type:
de <hallname> where <filename> should be something like "mowhall" (for the Masters of War guildhall).
Don't call the hall something generic like 'guild' or 'hall'. Make the name unique to your faction.
DE will bring up a few indicators letting you know it couldn't open any files (since they don't exist yet). It will then prompt you for the starting vnum for rooms, objects, and mobs. Enter the number that was given to you by the Guildhall admin.
Enter a name for the zone when prompted. Use something appropriate, such as "Masters of War Guildhall".
Enter the zone number that was given to you by the Guildhall admin. You should now be in the DE program looking at the first room of the hall.
Continued in 'help construct3'

3. Editting the zone flags ===========================
Type "edit zone". The zone name and number should be correct, since you entered them when you first created the zone. Type "C" to edit lifespan values and reset mode. Type "C" again to edit the reset mode. Change the value to "0" so the zone never resets. Type "D" to edit the miscellaneous bits. The zone should have the "D. No Teleport" bit set. Nothing else should be selected.
Continued in 'help construct4'

4. Laying out the golem room =============================
The first room in the guildhall must be the golem room, and it must be the room that will connect to the map. This first room can have two exits: one to the map and one into the hall. The exit to the map can be of any direction, but the exit into the hall cannot be a diagonal.
Edit the room and create an exit in the direction that you want to lead to the map. Link it to room -1. The Guildhall admin will link the hall to the map using this exit, once the guild is approved.
Continued in 'help construct5'

5. Rules for Rooms ===================
Each room should follow these rules:
Rooms must have an appropriate name and a room description.
The following flags should be chosen. Make sure nothing else is selected.
D. Indoors G. No Recall M. No Precipitation P. No Teleport X. No Summon Y. Guild Room Z. Twilight 2. No gate/planeshift
The "R. Heal" flag may be chosen, but this adds to the cost of the guildhall.
You may only have one healing room per hall. See the Prices section of this document to see how much a healing room costs.
The room should have sector type "B. City".
Rooms (except the golem) room can have any number of exits. Exits may not have any doors. Exits must be "reversible", which means if you go east from one room to get to another, you can go west to get back to the first room.
Rooms should have a fall percentage chance of 0%, a mana flag of 0, mana value of 0, current strength of 0, and current direction of 0 (all the default values).
Continued in 'help construct6'

6. Rules for Golems ===================
Each hall can have up to 4 golems. Golems must have an appropriate short name, long name, keywords, and description. These should correspond to one another in a logical fashion. For example, a golem could have:
Short name: "&+ga&n &+Gglowing&n &+ggreen&n &+Ggolem&n"
Long name: "&+gA golem made of&n &+Gglowing&n &+ggreen stone blocks passage to north.&n"
Keywords: green golem glowing _guildgolem_ assoc1_n_0 _nomoney_
Description: &+gA powerful magic has enchanted this solid block of green stone, creating a powerful guardian that blocks passage to the north. Occassionally, brilliant pulses of bright green flash through the substance that makes up this golem, like blood through veins.
Mobs must have the following keywords: golem _guildgolem_ assoc1_N_0 (see below for details) _nomoney_
You may not use other keywords to affect the golems, such as _size_ flags.
The assoc1_N_0 keyword varies from hall to hall. The "1" should be replaced with your association number, given to you by the Guildhall admin. The "N" should be replaced with the exit direction that leads further into the hall. The "0" should be left alone.
So, for a guild with association number 4, and an exit leading east into the hall, each golem would have the keyword:
assoc4_E_0
Remember, you may not have diagonal exits leading further into the hall.
Golems should have the following E. action flags: "B. Sentinel" "D. Is NPC" "G. Stays in zone" "L. Memory" "M. Can't be paralyzed" "N. Can't be summoned" "O. Can't be bashed" "Z. Breaks charm" "1. Protector"
Golems should have the following F. affect1 flags: "D. Detect Invis"
Golems should not have any affect2, affect3, or affect4 flags. Anything else that golems need is handled by the code. Golems should be species: "OG (golem)". Golems should have a hometown of "0 (none)". Golems should have an alignment of "0". Golems may only have a class of "1. Warrior", "6. Cleric", or "10. orcerer". Golems should be level 59. Golems should have a position and default position of "8 (standing)". Golems may be neuter, male, or female.
All values in the "M." section of the mob editor should be left at the default values of 0. Golems cannot have quest or shop information.
All golems must be placed in the first room of the guildhall. Golems may not have equipment. Golems cannot follow one another.
Continued in 'help construct7'

Rules for Shopkeepers =====================
A guild can have one shop and shopkeeper.
Shopkeepers should have an appropriate short name, long name, keywords, and description. These should correspond to each other in a logical fashion.
Shopkeepers should have the following E. action flags: B. Sentinel D. Is NPC G. Stays in Zone L. Memory
Shopkeepers can have no affect1/affect2/affect3/affect4 flags. Shopkeepers must have a race of "H. (humanoid)". Shopkeepers should have a hometown of "0 (none)". Shopkeepers should have an alignment of "0". Shopkeepers should have a class of "0 (none)". Shopkeepers should have a level of "1". Shopkeepers should have a position and default position of "8 (standing)". Shopkeepers can be neuter, male, or female. Section M. values should be left as the default values of 0. Shopkeepers cannot have quest information. Shopkeepers should have the following shop information:
A. List of Items the Shop Sells custom food vnum custom badge vnum * designates optional equipment
Note: Just add the above items to the shopkeeper. It will state "object not in this .OBJ file" (except for the custom food and badge).
Shopkeeper buy and sell modifiers should be kept at the default value of 1.00.
Shopkeepers should buy the following items: 1. Light source 2. Scroll 3. Wand 4. Staff 5. Weapon 6. Ranged Weapon 7. Missile 8. Treasure 9. Armor 10. Potion 11. Worn (not armor) 12. Other 13. Trash 15. Container 30. Quiver 31. Lockpick 32. Instrument 33. Spellbook 34. Totem 36. Scabbard 37. Shield
Shopkeepers should have appropriate shop messages (or the default ones). Shopkeepers should not have opening or closing times (leave the default values). Shops should not roam. Shop rooms are NOT set to be NO-MAGIC. Shopkeepers can be killed. Shopkeepers should not have racist information.
Continued in 'help construct8'

Rules for Custom Badges =======================
Each guild may have one custom badge. It should have an appropriate short name, long name, keywords, and extra description.
Badges must have the keyword "badge", in addition to any others it has.
Badges can only have wear flags: A. Takeable V. Worn as badge/insignia
Badges should be set to allow anyone to use them. Badges should be type "11 (worn (not armor))" Badges should not have any "apply" factors. Badges should have a weight of "0". Badges should have a worth of "1". Badges should have a condition of "100%". Badges should have no trap information. Badges should have no affect1/affect2/affect3/affect4 flags.
Continued in 'help construct9'

Rules for Custom Food =====================
Each guild hall can have one custom food type. This food should have the appropriate short name, long name, keywords, and extra descriptions.
Food should have no extra/extra2 flags. Food should have the wear flag of "1. Takeable". Food should be set to be usable by anyone. Food should have object type "19 (food)". Food should have a number of hours filled of "24". Food cannot be poisoned or have any other apply values. Food should have a weight of 0. Food should have a worth of 20 (2 silver). Food should have no trap information. Food should have no affect1/affect2/affect3/affect4 flags.
Continued in 'help construct10'

Rules for Custom Fountains ==========================
Each guild hall can have one or two fountains. You may only have two if one of them is a normal fountain, and the other is holy/unholy.
Fountains should have the appropriate short name, long name, keywords, and extra description.
Fountains should have no extra/extra2 flags. Fountains should have no wear flags. Fountains should be usable by all.
Fountains should be object type "17 (drink container)". They should have a value #1 (max. drink units) of "-1". They should have a value #2 (number of drink units left) of "-1". Fountains can contain "0. Water", "17. Holy Water", or "28. Unholy Water". Fountains cannot be poisoned. Fountains can have no "apply" values. Fountains should have a weight of "0". Fountains should have a worth of "0". Fountains should have a condition of "100%". Fountains should have no trap information. Fountains should have no affect1/affect2/affect3/affect4 values. Fountains cannot be placed in the golem room.
Continued in 'help construct11'

Rules for Custom Portals ========================
A guild hall may have a portal to a hometown on the same side of the racewars.
The portal should have the appropriate short name, long name, keywords, and extra description.
Portals should have no extra/extra2 flags. Portals should have no wear flags. Portals should be usable by all.
Portals should have the object type "25 (teleport)". The target room for a portal should be given to you by the Guildhall admin. The activating command for the portal should be "7 (enter)". The portal should have a charges of "-1". The portal should have no apply values. Portals should have a weight of 0. Portals should have a worth of 0. Portals should have a condition of "100%". Portals should have no trap information. Portals should have no affect1/affect2/affect3/affect4 flags. Portals cannot be placed in the golem room.
Continued in 'help construct12'

Costs =====
Submission Fee: 500 A basic hall: 7,000 Golem: 4,500 Additional room: 1,000 Inn: 750 Fountain: 500 Holy/Unholy Fountain: 1,750 Shop 2,000 Healing room: 3,500 Teleporter: 10,000 (first) 50,000 (second)
Payment must be made in platinum on the same day the guildhall is added to the map. It must be made by hand by one of the guild leaders.
A submission fee must be paid each time a guildhall is sent in. This means if you send in a hall, decide you need to change something, you will be fined an additional 500 platinum.
The inn, shop, and healing rooms are NOT additional rooms. They must be placed in existing rooms. So, for example, you can't buy a basic guildhall, an inn, a shop, and a healing room and have 8 rooms. You would buy the basic hall 3 rooms if you wanted 8 rooms total. You can place the inn, shop, and healing room in those 5 basic rooms, however.
Bulliten boards are free.
Teleporters allow instantaneous transportation from a guild hall to a 'friendly' city's inn. Teleporters are one-way from the guild hall to the inn.
When purchasing a teleporter for a guild hall, you must choose the 'friendly' city destination. Friendly cities are those which are the hometowns of a race on your side of the racewars. So, a goodie guild could install a teleporter that leads to the inn in Paranel, or an evil guild could install a teleporter to the Bloodrock inn.
The guild's first teleporter costs 10,000 platinum. The second costs 50,000 platinum. No guild can have more than 2 teleporters. The two teleporters do not have to have the same destination.
NOTE: The costs are for the guild as a whole, not per guildhall. So if you had two guildhalls, and wanted a teleporter in each one, the cost would be 60,000 platinum for both teleporters, and you would use up your maximum of 2 teleporters.
Once added, teleporters are permanent. They cannot be removed and the destination cannot be changed.
Stables are not allowed.
Guild chests are buggy currrently, and cannot be purchased.
You may NOT modify an existing guild. You can replace it (at full costs), but you will get no credit for the existing hall.
Information you must submit when you send the guildhall in: ===========================================================
Location on the map where you want it linked. Detailed breakdown of costs. Room vnum of the inn. You don't have to do anything in DE to create the inn. The inn is part of the mud code, and is added by the Guildhall admin. Mob vnums of the golems. Room vnum where the guild bulliten board should be located.

A stronger version of the "cutting breeze" spell, this spell does a decent amount of damage to it's target.

Half-elves are a combination of human and elven parents, and this mixed breeding usually causes them to be shunned by both sides. Usually humans and elves cannot have children, but in a few cases a normal birth occurs, often at the cost of the mother's life. This sad way to enter the world is just the start of what is usually a tough and unfair life for a half-elf.
Half-elves usually come in two types: those who try to fit in with "normal" society, and those with a chip on their shoulders who dare anyone to look down upon them because of their heritage.
Half-elves have a mixture of human and elven physical traits, being somewhat stronger and healthier than grey elves, but less so than a human.
Class list: Warrior, Sorcerer, Cleric, Thief, Assassin, Mercenary, Ranger, Earth Elementalist, Water Elementalist, Druid
Stats: Half-elves tend to be slightly weaker and frailer than humans, but are quicker and smarter than their related kin.

Size: Medium Innate abilities: Infravision Hometown: Shadowglade, Paranel

Halflings are a small humanoid race, blessed with amazing quickness and dexterity but hampered by their lack of size. Jovial and carefree by nature, halflings stand roughly half the size of a human (hence the name), and usually possess curly brown or dark hair, a light tan complexion, and a stout or heavy frame caused by the halfling tendancy to indulge in good food and spirits.
Halflings make excellent thieves because of their impressive quickness, but this has caused many people to shun or outcast the entire race. "All halflings are thieves, it's just some do it more often" is a popular saying.
Class list: Warrior, Sorcerer, Thief, Cleric
Stats: Nimble and quick, halflings are quick on their feet and just as fast with their hands. Weaker than humans, they aren't overly intelligent or wise either.

Size: Small Innate abilities: Infravision Hometown: Woodseer

Spell
Syntax: cast 'harbor of balance' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, Touch Aggressive: No Cumulative: No Duration: Dependant on proficiency of caster Type of Spell: Divination
The druids believe in the natural balance of the world, seeing the balance between the good and evil that exists. This spell protects the target against both extremes, acting as both a protection from good and protection from evil spell.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'harm' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: Yes Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of Spell: Necromancy
The harm spell attacks the lifeforce of the target, draining hit points from the victim. The amount of damage done varies based on the level of the caster.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'haste' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: No Cumulative: No Duration: Dependent on proficiency of the caster Type of Spell: Alteration
Haste dramatically speeds up the target, increasing the amount of attacks he gets per round. It will also counteract the effects of the "slowness" spell.
Hasted attacks take place "in-between" normal combat rounds.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'hawkvision' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, Touch Aggressive: No Cumulative: No Duration: Dependant on proficiency of the caster Type of spell: Animal
This spell causes the target's eyesight to sharpen, causing the target to hit more often.

Applied Skill:
Syntax: headbutt <target> Aggressive: Yes
Mercenaries are masters of the headbutting skill. Heabutt is used to strike an opponent in the head with ones own head. Headbutt causes damage to the target. The skill also has a chance of either knocking the target out or knocking the player trying to headbutt.
NOTE: If you or your opponent get knocked unconcious, you will be totally vulnerable to anyone!

Spell
Syntax: cast 'heal' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: No Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of spell: Alteration
This spell returns a larger number of hit points to the target than other spells such as 'cure critical wounds' or 'cure serious wounds'. It has the added benefit of curing blindness, just as the 'cure blindness' spell.

Syntax: help [keyword]
HELP without any arguments shows a one-page command summary.
HELP followed by a keyword will attempt to show you the help file related to that keyword.
HELP INDEX is a complete list of all information contained in the help files.
If your keywords match a help entry exactly, only that entry will be shown. If your keywords match more than one help entry partially but none exactly, then you will be shown every help entry with those keywords.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'herbal remedy' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, Touch Aggressive: No Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of Spell: Alteration
This spell calls upon the healing forces of nature to replenish a moderate amount of health to a single target.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'hex' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: Yes Cumulative: No Duration: Very short Type of Spell: Enchantment
This spell curses its victim for a short period of time. The victim becomes more clumsy and awkward and is much easier to hit. The effect of this spell becomes worse as the caster gains in proficiency.

Applied Skill
Syntax: hide Aggressive: No
Hide will attempt to conceal your character from the rest of the people in a room. There is a chance you will fail, based on your skill level. A player attempting to hide will not know if he has hidden or not. There is no failure or success message.
If you are hiding, you can only be sensed by the "sense life" spell.
Almost any command will bring you out of hiding. The effect of being hidden will also wear off over time.
Use this command the history of the commands you have entered.

WIELD is used for equipping weapons.
This command, as well as most object manipulation commands, allow the use of the #.object format, where # is a number or the word "all". This allows a player to choose a specific item from a group of items with the same keywords.
For example, if you had 2 swords and wanted to wield the second one, you
would type:
wield 2.sword

Syntax: holylight Syntax: wizinvis
HOLYLIGHT is a toggle that allows you to see (almost) every character and mobile in the game. With holy light, you can see what's in the game more easily. Without holy light, you can see what mortal players see.
WIZINVIS is a toggle which makes you completely invisible to all player characters of lower level than you, and to all mobiles.
HOLYLIGHT will not allow you to see immortal WIZINVIS characters who are higher level than you.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'holy word' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: Yes Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of Spell: Necromancy
This spell calls down the wrath of the gods on those of evil alignment. It does a great deal of damage and can cause instant death, major paralysis, blindness, or stunning, depending on the differences between the levels of the caster and his target.
If a person of evil alignment casts this spell, it can have deadly side effects.

Hometowns are zones in which players are first "born" into the world.
Hometowns are places of great trade of many kinds, where there are often shops, banks and inns. Hometowns are usually guarded by strong warriors to ensure the relative safety of the inhabitants.
NOTE: Goodie hometowns are often considerably safer than Evil hometowns.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'hover' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, Touch Aggressive: No Cumulative: No Duration: Dependant on proficiency of caster Type of Spell: Enchantment
This spell allows the target to levitate a few inches about the ground, allowing him to pass more easily over difficult or broken terrain.

The Human race is younger than most of the other races of good alignment, but already they have become one of the most powerful and numerous. Humans have been blessed (or cursed) with an amazing curiousity and desire to expand and conquer. Humans are very adept at living in a wide range of conditions and can be found almost anywhere.
Humans are more tolerant of other races and more open-minded about their views of the world. They're also one of the more warlike of the good aligned races and conflicts between humans and elves, dwarves, and other humans are common. Because of this, some of the older races view the humans as untrustworthy and hot-headed.
Class list: Warrior, Sorcerer, Cleric, Thief, Assassin, Mercenary, Paladin, Ranger, Earth Elementalist, Air Elementalist, Fire Elementalist, Water Elementalist, Druid, Illusionist
Stats: Humans are the baseline against which all other races are compared. As a result, they have no strengths or weaknesses.

When a player is hungry they must eat some food. If one neglects eating for too long they will regenerate movement and hit points at a very slower pace. In extreme conditions of hunger a player will lose hit points and could even lead to death.

Hunters are the scouts and rangers of the Underdark. Trained to survive the incredibly dangerous caverns and tunnels of the underworld, these hunters are skilled fighters. They have unique skills and spells that help them survive away from the cities of the UD.
Hunters have limited spellcasting abilities, which increases as they gain in level and learn to harness the raw forces of the magic of illusions and alteration.
Important Attributes: Strength, Dexterity, Agility, Intelligence
Races: Drow Elf
Equipment: Hunters can use almost all weapons and armor. They are limited in the types of magical items such as wands, staves, or scrolls.

Masters of deception, Illusionists conjure phantasms in order to distort perception. The Illusionst relies on non-existance to sway beliefs and common sense of those who view the magical illusion. What is reality? Entities that lack intelligence are much more susceptible to the magical effects of an Illusion. Creatures like Ogres and Centaurs will undoubtably lack the cognizance to see an Illusion for what it is.
Illusionsts are also able to cast other sorts of magical spells since the Illusionist is also a practicitioner of Magic. Yet, the Illusionist uses non-illusion spells to augment their own spells.
Very powerful Illusionists are capable of mixing illusion with reality to provide an effect that does possess real aspects. These powerful spells are also capable of drawing creatures from the Plane of Shadow for short periods of time. These Shadow creatures can cause devestating results to the person who is their chosen victim. The culmination of reality with illusion gives powerful Illusionists a vast arsenal.
Important Attributes: Intelligence
Races: Human, Gnome, Rakshasa
Equipment: Illusionists are spellcasters and are very limited in their use of weapons and armor. They have an unsurpassed ability to use magical objects such as staves, wands, and scrolls.

Innates are bestowed upon players due to specifics with their race and or class. Some innates are continuous and require no effort by the player. Other innates require a command in order to activate the innate.
Examples of innates that're continuous: Shrug, Ultravision, Infravision Examples of innates that require a command: Strength, Summon Mount
To see a list of innates for your character type 'innates'.

Reflexive/Applied Skill:
Syntax: backstab <target>
Instant Kill can happen during an assassin backstabs. The skill is based greatly on both the level of the target and the level of the stabber. Instant Kills pay no heed to the opponents hit points as the kill is instant.

Attribute
Intelligence is a measure of quickness and accuracy of thought. Basically, it measures how well you can think. Intelligence is the primary attribute for all magic using classes and can be useful to other classes as well.
Some races are blessed with higher intelligence than others. For example, gnomes, grey elves, and drow elves are known for their high levels of intelligence, while trolls, barbarians, and ogres are at the opposite end of the spectrum.

INVENTORY will list everything you have that is not being worn, wielded, or held in your hands. It will not show you things inside container (use the LOOK IN command to do that), nor will it show you undetectable items (invisible items if you cannot detect invisible, for example).
You can only carry so many items in your inventory.

Applied Skill
Syntax: kick <target> Aggressive: yes
Kicking is a skill used by the certain classes as an extra attack in battle. There is a slight delay after using the kick ability as the character recovers his balance after the attack. Larger creatures, when they kick smaller ones, have the ability to "wall-kick" them. This will fling the victim against a nearby wall or even out of the room.

Aggressive: yes
Kill is the command used to engage an enemy. This is a blatant attempt to end either a players or a mobs life. It can also be used in battle to switch opponents. For example, if you are fighting an Ogre and you wish to attack a Rakshasa you would use the 'kill rakshasa' command to switch.
Hit will also perform the same action as kill.

Each race has it's own language. Most players can speak their native language perfectly, but also start with a small amount of proficiency in speaking and understanding languages of other races.
If you do not have a high level of understanding of a language, when it is spoken it will seem garbled or difficult to comprehend, or if you attempt to speak it your own words will be garbled to anyone who hears you.
By being in contact with people who speak a language, you gain understanding gradually as you listen.
You use the SPEAK command to change which language you are speaking.

This spell when cast creates a curtain of lightning that blocks a single exit. If someone tries to pass though this barrier, they will take a small amount of electrical damage.

Syntax: cast 'lightning bolt' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: Yes Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of spell: Evocation
This spell throws a bolt of lightning from the caster's raised palms hitting the victim and doing some moderate electric damage to their system.

Spell

This spell increases the target's strength and damage-dealing ability, while decreasing his agility. Because of the spell's detrimental effects, the target will save against it. Thus, if the target wants to be the recipient, he should "consent" the caster.

LIST will let you check to see what a shopkeeper is selling.
LIST with no argument is the same thing as LIST ALL. Both of these list all the objects the shopkeeper is trying to sell and their prices.
LIST [object] will list only the items that contain that keyword, allowing you to filter the list of items.
If no shopkeeper is specified, the first shopkeeper in the room will be chosen.
Prices in shops can be affected by a player's charisma.

Syntax: log <character> Syntax: log all Syntax: snoop <character>
LOG <character> causes all of a character's commands to be logged into the server's log file. Like FREEZE, it is a permanent character toggle.
Certain commands (PASSWORD) are protected against LOG. Conversely, certain commands (especially immortal commands) are always logged.
LOG ALL logs all character commands. It is a server-wide toggle; it does not persist across reboots.

Syntax: look Syntax: look room Syntax: look <object|character|direction> Syntax: look in <container|corpse>
LOOK is used for studying your surrounding or inspection of an object or person.
LOOK by itself will give a brief summary of the room you are in. LOOK ROOM will give a longer description of the room.
LOOK <direction> will look at any exits in that direction, giving you a description of the exit and, if possible, the room beyond. LOOK <direction> is often used in conjunction with items that grant the ability to farsee.
LOOK <object> can be used to look at something in your inventory or something in the room. Oftentimes rooms will have extra things to look at, sometimes providing vital clues to the player.
LOOK can be abbreviated to "L".

Attribute
Luck is difficult to describe. Some people are just born lucky. It may be caused by some cosmic karmic balance, or the gods taking a special interest in a person, or some natural innate ability to influence fate. Luck can have strange effects on the game, but it isn't a prime attribute for any class. Needless to say, however, all classes can benefit from high luck scores.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'magic missile' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: Yes Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of spell: Invocation
Magic missile sends a barrage of missiles of pure energy at the caster's victim. The amount of missiles generated is dependant on the level of the caster.

Magma is the name of the original codebase that Basternae 2: Phoenix Rising was based upon. It was derived from UltraEnvy 0.87j, which was derived from Envy 2.2 which was derived from Merc 2.2 which was derived from DikuMud.
Magma 3.0.x was the last public release of the MagmaMUD codebase.
ModernMUD is a new codebase. It was rewritten from scratch and does not include any Diku/Merc/Envy legacy code.

"Malison" curses the target, causing him to be more susceptible to magical attacks.

Spell

"Mass Dispel Magic" is an area-effect version of the spell "dispel magic". It will affect everyone in the room that is not in the caster's group.

This spell returns a number of hit points to the caster and every occupant of the room, just as if each individual had been targetted with a 'heal' spell.

Help.Text:
Applied Skill
Meditating allows a caster to memorize his spells at an increased rate of speed. The caster concentrates on his magic, possibly halving the time it takes him to commit a spell to memory. Because of the intense focus the meditation takes, almost any action will break the caster out of his trance.

MEMORY reports the size of your mud.
Each line shows the quantity of a particular class that has been instantiated. While this will not give an exact amount of memory used, it does let you know the size of your world database.

This spell heals the target a fair amount, up to his maximum hitpoints.

Fighter sub-class
The mercenary is a blend of fighter and rogue, having some of the skills of each. While he can't match the warrior in fighting skills nor the assassin in backstabbing abilities, the skills that the mercenary possess combine some of the best from both worlds.
Mercenaries are soldiers for hire, bounty hunters, pirates, and smugglers. They have the unique ability to try and capture a foe, and at high levels of experience they learn how to crush the throat of a spellcaster. Mercenaries also have the headbutt skill, which they can use and attempt to knock out or daze an opponent.
Important Attributes: Strength, Agility, Dexterity, Constitution
Races: Barbarian, Mountain Dwarf, Half-elf, Orc, Duergar Dwarf, Troll, Ogre Flind, Minotaur, Human
Equipment: Mercenaries are a fighter-rogue hybrid. They can use most weapons. Their choice of armor is extensive, but still somewhat limited when compared to a warrior.
Innate Abilities: None
See also: MERCENARY SKILLS

Minotaurs are large bull-like humanoids that look like a combination of bull-head with a humanoid lower body. They walk upright on two legs, and are powerful creatures, their strength surpassed only by the massive ogres and centaur races. Minotaurs are not especially bright, but they do have a keen sense of cunning and a vicious streak a mile wide. Minotaurs are extremely unfriendly to most outsiders, preferring the company of their own kind.
Class list: Warrior, Mercenary, Shaman
Stats: Strong and hearty, the minotaur people are a combination of man and beast and take some of the best traits of each. Stronger by far than humans, they are less slightly less intelligent and wise.

A mount is also a term used to describe the animal you ride.

Applied Skill
Fighting from the back of a mount is more difficult and tricky than fighting while on foot and this skill represents the character's ability to do so. It affects a character's ability to hit and do damage while riding a mount in a combat situation.

Ogres are massive, ugly humanoids, standing nine to ten feet in height and weighing between 300 to 400 pounds. Ill-tempered and nasty, ogres are feared by most other races because of their incredible strength and warlike nature.
Ogres normally live in tribes, ruled by the strongest. They constantly fight one another and can not be trusted to keep their word. Some ogres focus on the arts of shamanism, but most prefer to pursue the simpler life of a warrior.
Class list: Warrior, Mercenary, Shaman
Stats: Ogres have a reputation for stupidity and sluggish behavior. The raw strength and constitution of these creatures make them powerful predators.

Orcs are a race of evil humanoids, some say a twisted mockery of the human race. They typically stand five to six feet tall and have pale yellow, brown, or greenish skin and red eyes. Orcs are the most social of the evil races, and are known to build huge warbands that invade and pillage the lands of the good races until they are destroyed.
Orcs have roughly the same attributes as humans as well, further hinting at some link between the two species, although what that link may be has been lost in time.
Class list: Warrior, Anti-Paladin, Sorcerer, Thief, Assassin, Mercenary, Cleric, Shaman, Air Elementalist, Earth Elementalist
Stats: Orcs are almost mirror images of humans, possessing a little more strength and constitution, but a little less intelligence and wisdom.

Fighter sub-class
Paladins are holy warriors, people who fight for their gods and attempt to bring good to the world. Paladins are given some limited spellcasting abilities by their gods, but only as long as they strive to destroy what is evil and vile in the world. Paladins are experts with two-handed weapons, gaining bonuses to hit as they go up in level. In addition, paladins have a much higher chance of successfully bashing an opponent without using a shield.
Paladins can detect evil and have the ability to summon a mount when the need arises. Paladins can also layhands, channelling the healing power of their god onto themselves or another person.
Paladins cannot group with anti-paladins, and most likely would attack such an evil creature on sight.
Important Attributes: Strength, Dexterity, Agility, Wisdom Races: Human, Dwarf Equipment: Paladins can use almost all weapons and armor. They arel imited in the types of magical items such as wands, staves, or scrolls. Innate Abilities: Layhands, Detect Evil, Summon Mount (at level 10), Protection from Evil
Paladins, because of their religious nature, may NOT toggle vicious to on. They cannot toggle AGGR on either. Paladins can also LOSE experience from attacking good-aligned creatures. The following chart gives you an idea of how experience is calculated for paladins:
Victim is evil or neutral with alignment less than 0: Full experience as normal
Victim is neutral with alignment equal to or more than zero and aggressive: Gain 1/5th normal experience
Victim is neutral with alignment equal to or more than zero and not aggressive: Lose 1/5th normal experience
Victim is good and aggressive: Gain 1/50th normal experience
Victim is good and non-aggressive: Lose experience equal to the normal amount
See also: PALADIN SKILLS, PALADIN SPELLS, LAYHANDS, SUMMON MOUNT

Pets are creatures who follow a player, taking orders and performing some basic tasks. Pets can be purchased in stores, summoned from spells (such as elementals or a necromancer's undead followers), or obtained via other means.
Most mobs consider the owner of the pet to be responsible for the pet's actions. If the pet attacks, the mob will most likely come after the owner of the pet if the pet is killed. Towns with justice systems may arrest pet owners if the pet breaks any laws.
Pets are commanded using the ORDER command.
Some pets gradually tire of taking orders and cease to follow their masters.
You cannot rent with pets. Once you have rented, your pets will forget all about you and you must obtain new ones.

PETITION allows you to send a message to all the gods who are currently online. This is used for critical problems or errors and should not be used to offer suggestions, report minor bugs, or report typos in zones.
PETITION should be used for critical bugs and reporting cheating.
Do NOT use PETITION to check and see if a god is online. If they wanted you to know they were online, they'd go visible.
Do not abuse this command, or your ability to use it may be removed.

PKILL is the main focus of ModernMUD. A PKILL is anytime one player kills another. When a player PKILLs a player from the other side of the race war that is close to them in level, they receive a frag.
A Frag is a measure of a players PKILLing success. If a level 50 kills another level 50 they receive a frag. If a level 50 kills a level 1 player they won't get a frag. A person is not fraggable until they are above level 20.

From the journals of Lord Gorinae, the Planeswalker...
There are many planes of existance on which the creatures of the multi-verse live. Many know only of the "True Prime", the land of Magma itself. Some narrowminded people think of this as our planet alone, but this is not necessarily true. The sun, other planetary systems, the stars... all reside in the True Prime.
The other planes are completely different realms of existence. They do not touch our True Prime except by magical means. These different planes are accessible through many different spells such as 'plane shift', 'gate', and the like. Some creatures seem to have an innate ability to shift themselves from one plane to another.
To visualize the layout of the major planes of existence, think of the Astral as a large diamond or sphere. Along the equator of this sphere are the Elemental Planes, spaced out equally. The "opposing" elements are across from one another (earth to air, fire to water). Between these Elemental Planes are the Paraelemental Planes, where two Elemental Planes intersect.
At the top of this sphere, there's the Positive Elemental Plane, and it's opposite the Negative resides at the bottom.
Then, to top it all off, each of the Elemental Planes interacts with the Positive and Negative, just as they interact with each other. This creates the Quasielemental Planes.
In theory, there could be an infinite amount of Elemental-related planes, each caused by the lack of true "borders" between each of them. The Paraelemental Planes should interact with the Positive and Negative, and so on. This theory hasn't been proven by any explorers that I am familar with.
The Ethereal seems to exist everywhere and nowhere. It's the realm of the Demi-Planes, islands of matter in the Deep Ethereal that act much like the True Prime in many cases. Notable examples of this phenomenon are the Demi-Plane of Dreams, the Demi-Plane of Shadows, and the Demi-Plane of Dread.
Planes that are most commonly known are:
Astral - a dull silver expanse that seems to serve as a nexus for portals to other planes. Ethereal - another misty realm, though this one is full of color. Split up into the Border Ethereal and the Deep Ethereal.
The Elemental Planes (sometimes called the Inner Planes) - these are the places where the elementalist mages draw their power.
Fire Water Earth Air
The Positive and Negative Energy Planes - places of almost pure energy of lack thereof. The Positive is a place of radiance, where the power can burn out a traveler in an instant. The Negative is the opposite, a place of cold and void, where the spirit is sucked from the soul.
The Paraelemental Planes - where two adjacent Elemental planes touch.
Magma (Fire + Earth) Smoke (Fire + Air) Ooze (Earth + Water) Ice (Air + Water)
The Quasielemental Planes - where a Elemental Plane touches the Positive and Negative.
Lightning (Air + Positive) Vacuum (Air + Negative) Mineral (Earth + Positive) Dust (Earth + Negative) Steam (Water + Positive) Salt (Water + Negative) Radiance (Fire + Positive) Ash (Fire + Negative)
The True Prime may be dangerous to some, but these other planes of existance are very deadly and should only be attempted by those of great skill and mental fortitude.
See Also: ZONES, CREDITS

Syntax: prompt Syntax: prompt raw Syntax: prompt dark Syntax: prompt meter Syntax: prompt chains Syntax: prompt status Syntax: prompt <%*>
PROMPT with out an argument will turn your prompt on or off. PROMPT RAW will give you the standard "<hits mana moves>" prompt with tank and enemy status when in combat. PROMPT DARK will give you a more sinister "<hits moves>" prompt with colorful tank and enemy status in combat. PROMPT METER will give you the standard prompt with life meters for your tank and enemy status when in combat. PROMPT CHAINS will give you the DARK prompt with life meters for your tank and enemy status when in combat. PROMPT STATUS will give you the raw prompt showing your current position. PROMPT <%*> where the %* are the various variables you may set yourself. %h : Display your current hits %H : Display your maximum hits %m : Display your current mana %M : Display your maximum mana %v : Display your current moves %V : Display your maximum moves %x : Display your current experience %g : Display your gold held %l : Display your current position %a : Display your alignment %r : Display the room name you are in %R : Display the vnum you are in (IMMORTAL ONLY) %z : Display the area name you are in (IMMORTAL ONLY) %i : Display whether or not you are invisible %I : Display whether or not you are wizinvis (IMMORTAL ONLY) %c : Display the editing mode you are in (IMMORTAL ONLY) %C : Display the number of the area you are editing (IMMORTAL ONLY) %p : Display your status as 'Chains' meter when in combat %P : Display your status as text_1 when in combat %q : Display your status as 'Plus' meter when in combat %Q : Display your status as text_2 when in combat %e : Display you enemy's status as "Chains" meter when in combat %E : Display your enemy's status as text_1 when in combat %b : Display you enemy's status as "Plus" meter when in combat %B : Display your enemy's status as text_2 when in combat %t : Display the tank's status as "Chains" meter when in combat %T : Display the tank's status as text_1 when in combat %d : Display the tank's status as "Plus" meter when in combat %D : Display the tank's status as text_2 when in combat
Example:
PROMPT <%h/%Hhp %m/%Mm %v/%Vmv><%t %e>
Will set your prompt to:
<9/10hp 99/100m 75/100mv><Tank(=-=-=-=-=) Enemy(=-=-=-=-=)>

Psionicists are a class that has amazing control over their minds, allowing them to master the hidden power of the mind itself. Psionicists use this internal power to advance their causes, whatever those may be. Psionicists use the 'will' command to focus their energies, much like a magic-user does while casting.
Psionicists don't require a spellbook, however. When they gain levels, they automatically gain the power and ability to cast new spells. The spells a psionicist learns cover a wide variety of abilities.
Psionicists use mana to cast spells. They can continue to cast spells until their reserve of mana is exhausted. At that point, they must rest and regenerate mana before they can cast spells again.
Important Attributes: Intelligence, Wisdom
Races: Githyanki
Equipment: Psionicists are spellcasters and are very limited in their use of weapons and armor. They have an unsurpassed ability to use magical objects such as staves, wands, and scrolls.

Syntax: purge Syntax: purge <character>
PURGE is used to clean up the world. PURGE with no arguments removes all the NPC's and objects in the current room. PURGE with an argument purges one character from anywhere in the world.
PURGE will not get rid of PC's.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'purify' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, Touch Aggressive: No Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of Spell: Alteration
This spell blankets the target in a healing natural magic, after which the target is freed from any poisons in his system and the effects of magical blindness are removed.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'purify spirit' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, Touch Aggressive: No Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of Spell: Spirit
"Purify spirit" cleanses the spirit of the target, removing blindness, curse, and malison.

Syntax: put <object|all> <container> Syntax: put <amount> <coin type> <container>
PUT will put an object inside a container.
Some containers have a maximum amount of weight or internal room and will not hold large or heavy objects.
PUT, as well as most object manipulation commands, allows the use of the #.object format, where # is a number or the word "all". This allows a player to choose a specific item from a group of items with the same keywords.
For example, if you had 3 spellbooks and wanted to put them all in a backpack, you would type:
put all.spellbook backpack
Make sure you include the period between the number of the item and the name. If you used a space in the above example instead of a period, you would attempt to put everything you had in your inventory into your spellbook.
See also: GET, DROP, GIVE, MONEY

Spell
Syntax: cast 'pythonsting' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: Yes Cumulative: No Duration: Varies Type of spell: Animal
This spell causes a poisonous python to appear for a brief second, biting the target (doing minor damage) and possibly poisoning the target.

Syntax: qui
QUI prevents you from accidentally typing QUIT when you don't want to.
The command parser attempts to complete commands. For example, if you want to go EAST, you can type E, EA, EAS, or EAST. The mud will interpret any of those to be the command EAST.
QUI prevents you from quitting the game if you mistakenly type a Q, QU, or QUI.

Help.Text:
Reflexive Skill
The quick chant skill represents a character's ability to occassionally get off a spell just slightly quicker than normal. The higher your skill level, the more likely you are to cast a spell in roughly half the time it would normally take.

Syntax: quit (disabled for players)
QUIT leaves the game immediately. It can only be used by administrators. Players must either RENT or CAMP to leave the game.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'raging circle of flames' Area of Effect: Room Aggressive: No Cumulative: No Duration: Dependant on proficiency of the caster Type of Spell: Evocation
A raging circle of fire springs up around the caster, encircling those that are in the same room as him, preventing exit. Attempts to pass through the walls of fire will result in a small amount of damage.

Rakshasas are a race of evil spirits encased in flesh. Standing between six and seven feet tall, they appear as humanoid creatures with the bodily features of animals, usually tigers and apes. Rakshasa are enemies of humanity, waging a constant war for reasons unknown to any but the Rakshasa.
Magical in nature, Rakshasas make excellent spellcasters and have an innate resistance to magical attacks. They are honorable creatures but also tend to be manipulative and deceptive, twisting arguments to suit their purposes.
It is rumored that a Rakshasa is especially vulnerable to attacks from blessed missile weapons.
Class list: Warrior, Sorcerer, Thief, Assassin, Anti-Paladin, Air Elementalist, Fire Elementalist, Water Elementalist, Illusionist
Stats: Rakshasa tend to be weaker than their human enemies, but quicker and more intelligent.
STR: Below Average INT: Above Average DEX: Above Average WIS: Average AGI: Very Good CHA: Good CON: Below Average
Size: Medium Innate abilities: Ultravision, Underdark Sneak (except sorcerers, shamans, conjurers, and illusionists), Shrug Hometown: Rakropolis
See also: RACES, INNATE, ULTRAVISION, SNEAK, SHRUG

Fighter sub-class
Rangers are fighters who are trained in outdoor survival and combat. Rangers lack some of the raw, physical power of a warrior, but make up for it with the unsurpassed abilities they have in wielding two weapons at once.
Rangers, because of their nature, have a unique set of skills that helps them survive in the wilderness. They have a link with nature, and are at their best when fighting in a natural environment.
Rangers have limited spellcasting abilities, which increases as they gain in level and learn to harness the raw forces of the magic of nature.
Important Attributes: Strength, Dexterity, Agility, Intelligence
Races: Grey Elf, Half-Elf, Human
Equipment: Rangers can use almost all weapons and armor. They are limited in the types of magical items such as wands, staves, or scrolls.
Innate Abilities: Outdoor Sneak
See also: RANGER SKILLS, RANGER SPELLS, SPELLBOOKS

Spell
Syntax: cast 'ravenflight' <target> Area of effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: Yes Cumulative: No Duration: Dependent on proficiency of the caster Type of spell: Animal
This spell grants the target the ability to fly like a raven, allowing him to fly over water, ground, and through the mid-air with relative ease.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'ravenous vines' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: Yes Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of Spell: Summoning
This spell calls forth several small vines to spring from the ground and firmly grasp a single target, crushing it in a vice-like grip and doing a small amount of damage.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'ray of enfeeblement' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: Yes Cumulative: N/A Duration: Depedant on level of the caster Type of spell: Alteration
The target's body becomes incredibly weak if it doesn't save against this spell's effects. The effects of this spell hamper the target's ability to fight in battle until it is dispelled or wears off.
Use the read command when you wish to read something, such as a book, sign, or bulletin board.
REBOOT shuts down the server. When the normal 'startup' script is used to control the server, a delay of sixty seconds will ensue (to allow old connections to die), followed by a reboot.
RECITE reads a magical scroll. The target may be optional, depending on the type of scroll. Because scrolls are magic, they will have no effect in a "no-magic" area.

Recline is a command used to make a person lay down. This can be done while the player is standing or sitting. Reclining allows a player to "slither". This form of crawling expends a massive amount of movement points.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'reduce' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: No Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of spell: Enchantment
This spell decreases the targets size by one class. It can only take the target down one size level and cannot be stacked. It will cancel out the effects of an "enlarge" spell.

Innate Ability
Regeneration is an innate used by Trolls to gain back hit points in a manner faster than any other race. This innate is proportional to the level of the troll.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'rejuvenate' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, Touch Aggressive: No Cumulative: Yes Duration: Permanent Type of Spell: Enchantment
This spell permanently reduces the target's age, with the amount dependent on the proficiency of the caster. The reduction in age carries all the benefits and detriments normally associated with being younger. This is a permanent age change.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'relocate' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: No Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of spell: Alteration
Similar to dimension door, this spell transfers the caster to the target. The distance between the caster and target does not matter, but both rooms must not be magically shielded against teleportation types of spells.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'remove curse' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room, or Single Object, In-Inventory Aggressive: No Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of spell: Enchantment
This spell will remove a "curse" on any person or object. To remove the curse on an item, the item must be in the caster's inventory for the spell to work properly. To rid oneself of a cursed item, equip the item, then receive a "remove curse" spell; the item will drop to the ground.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'remove poison' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room or Single Item Aggressive: No Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of Spell: Alteration
This spell will attempt to remove the effects of poison from a single person or object.

RENT allows you to exit the game. It can only be performed at an inn. It will store all your items and save your character. The next time you enter the game you will re-enter at the spot where you rented. RENTing in an inn does not cost anything and your items are stored free of charge.

Help.Text: REPLY sents a message to the last person who sent you a tell. REPLY will work even if you can't see the player, without revealing their identity. This is handy for talking to invisible or flying people.

REPORT by itself will show your current statistics to you and everyone in your room.
REPORT followed by a player name will send a TELL to that player giving him your current statistics.

Applied Skill:
Syntax: rescue <target> Aggressive: yes
The rescue skill allows a fighter to leap in front of one of his comrades, stepping between the target and his foe. The opponent will be forced to switch and begin fighting the rescuer, and the target will escape from melee combat.
This skill will only rescue the target from one foe per successful attempt. If a target is being hit by multiple attackers, multiple rescues will be needed before he is safe from harm.

REST allows a person to regenerate movement points and health back at an increased rate. You must also REST before trying to memorize or pray for spells.
You are more vulnerable to attacks while resting.

RESTORE restores full hit points, mana points, and movement points to the target character.
RESTORE ALL restores full hit points, mana points, and movement points to all players and mobiles.
RESTORE should not be used to give any special advantage to players. Instead, its main use should be to refresh everyone before a game reboot.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'resurrect' <corpse> Area of Effect: Single corpse, requires consent Aggressive: No Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of spell: Necromancy
This spell will restore life to a corpse, negating most of the experience lost by the death. The power of this spell takes a toll on both the cleric and the target and both are exhausted by the procedure.
This spell is not without risks, however. If the person being resurrected has low constitution, the strain of being resurrected may be too great, in which case the spell may fail, and the corpse will be incapable of being restored to life.
You must have the target's consent before performing a resurrection or the spell will fail.

Syntax: cast 'reveal spirit essence' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: No Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of spell: Spirit
This spell allows the caster to see the essence or alignment of the target PC. It may only be caster on players and mobs, not on items.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'reveal true form' Area of Effect: Room Aggressive: No Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of spell: Spiritual
"Reveal true form" reveals all hidden and invisible PCs and NPCs in the room, including those in the caster's group.

Spell

This spell reveals the true name of a disguised or unknown person or object.

Reflexive Skill:
The riposte ability is an advanced form of a parry, where in addition to knocking aside your opponent's attacks, you then strike at your opponent and do a minor hit of your own. A riposte can only be done after a successful parry and thus this skill depends heavily on the character's parry proficiency.

Ritual Spell
Syntax: cast 'ritual of greater journey' <target> Area of Effect: Group Aggressive: No Cumulative: No Duration: Long Type of Spell: Teleportation
Requires two druids.
This ritual, when completed, conjures up a small moonwell, per the "moonwell" spell. Because of the power involved in such portal spells, this ritual's magical gate can only transport a few people before it dissipates, although this ritual can transport more people than the "ritual of lesser journey".
The druid who initiates the spell must be able to see the target, who must be a PC. This means that if the target is invisible and the lead druid cannot see him, the spell will fail.

Requires two druids.
This ritual, when completed, conjures up a small moonwell, per the "moonwell" spell. Because of the power involved in such portal spells, this ritual's magical gate can only transport a few people before it dissipates.
The druid who initiates the spell must be able to see the target, who must be a PC. This means that if the target is invisible and the lead druid cannot see him, the spell will fail.

Ritual Spell
Syntax: cast 'ritual of protection' Area of Effect: Group Aggressive: No Cumulative: No Duration: Long Type of Spell: Enchantment
Requires two druids.
This ritual, when completed, protects the druids' entire group (or groups) from the effects of fire, acid, cold, gas, and lightning.

Requires three druids.
This ritual, when completed, infuses the druids' group (or groups) with a sense of health and vitality. It increases the maximum hit points of everyone in the group(s), per the "vitality" spell, although the amount of health gained is somewhat less than with that spell.

Ritual Spell

Requires two druids.
This ritual, when completed, refreshes the druids' group (or groups), filling them as if they had eaten a hearty meal.

Requires two druids.
This ritual, when completed, restores a bit of energy to the druids' group, replenishing a small amount of movement points.

Ritual Spell

Requires two druids.
This ritual, when completed, bathes the druids' group (or groups) with a healing energy that refreshes and nourishes each member.

Rituals are a special form of magic, practiced only by druids. Certain spells require more power than a single caster can produce. Multiple druids, working in concert with one another, can call upon the spirit of the natural world to do their bidding, producing more powerful effects than a lone druid could manage.
Most rituals have long casting times, but make up for that hindrance with longer durations and better effects.
Rituals will have a minimum number of druids that must be involved to cast the spell. The druids must be of a certain level. If more druids of the appropriate level assist in the casting of the ritual, the spell will take effect sooner.

Saurials are a race of lizardmen who make their homes deep in large, exotic jungle cities. A race that prefers to stay isolated and keep outsiders away, the saurials are extremely loyal to one another and the sprawling temple-cities they inhabit.
Saurials are larger and more bulkier than humans. Because of their cold-blooded nature, they can be a bit lethargic at times and dislike inclimate weather, preferring heated and wet environments such as tropical rain forests.
Class list:

Applied skill
Magic users must have their spells written in special books, which are then used during the memorization process for the spells. This spellbook is assumed to always be with the cashter, even after he dies. You do NOT need to carry around a spellbook to cast spells.

SELL, as well as most object manipulation commands, allows the use of the #.object format, where # is a number or the word "all". This allows a player to choose a specific item from a group of items with the same keywords.
For example, if the command "LIST DAGGER" showed you that a shopkeeper had five daggers, you could type "BUY 3.DAGGER".
Make sure you include the period between the number of the item and the name. If you used a space in the above example instead of a period, you would attempt to buy three daggers, not the third dagger.
Prices in shops can be affected by a player's charisma.

Priest sub-class
Shamans wield the forces of nature, the elements, and the spirit world, using totems to focus their powers into terrific magical effects. This spell decreases the target's strength and damage-dealing ability, causing him to be less of a threat to the caster.

The room is silenced, preventing all audible communication.

Sit is a command used to either sit down from a standing position or to sit up from a reclining position. Sitting prevents you from moving in any direction. Mobs also tend to attack those who are sitting down during a fight.

Every creature on Magma has a size classification. This size is used for certain skills, such as bash and springleap. These skills have restrictions on the sizes of creatures they can be used on relative to the size of the player issuing the command.
For example, a player can only bash a creature that is his own size, up to two sizes larger, or down to two sizes smaller.
In addition to the restrictions, there may be penalties for attempting to use skills on races that aren't the same size as you. You can bash something two size classes smaller, but you'll have a harder time doing it.
+----------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+ | Size | Example Races | +----------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+ | tiny | worms, rats, bats | | small | halfling, gnome, goblin | | small-medium | grey elf, drow elf, mountain dwarf, duergar dwarf | | medium | human, rakshasa, half-elf, flind, orc, githyanki, | | | githzerai, thri-kreen, aquatic elf | | medium-large | barbarian, minotaur | | large | centaur, troll | | huge | ogre | | giant | giant | | titanic | hydra | | gargantuan | dragon, devil | +----------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+
Please keep in mind the sizes are not simply based on how tall or heavy a race is. Other factors such as the strength and physique of the creature play a part in what size a creature is.
However, and we can't stress this enough, one of the most important factors we used was game balance, especially where racewars are considered. Let's look at an example:
The ogre is arguably the best warrior class for players on the evil side of the racewars. As a huge creature, it can only bash down to medium-large level, which means it can bash centaurs and barbarians for the most part. Even reduced, the ogre can only bash medium, which still means most of the goodie caster races are immune.
This means that race/class combinations that weren't used on Basternae 1 as much are more valuable on Magma. A duergar warrior, for example, would have no troubles bashing most of the goodie caster races. Human and orc paladins/anti-paladins may not be able to do the damage of the warriors of a bigger race, but they can keep casters on the ground easier. It's a trade-off.
Also notice that some mobs can be larger or smaller than an "average" creature of that race. The "enlarge" and "reduce" spells also can affect a creature's size.
There are many individual skills in ModernMUD. The skills can be advanced by both use of them and by level increases.

This immortal command kills a character or mob in cold blood, no saving throw.
The optional argument <method> lets you pick the method of the victim's demise. Valid methods are immolate, pounce, slit, shatter, and squeeze.

Help.Text:
Command
The command is used for falling asleep, which will increase the rate at which a player can regenerate health and movement points. However, the sleeping character is much more vulnerable to attacks while asleep.
You must use the ALERT command to come to your senses fully after sleeping. When you awake, you're relaxed until you attempt to become more alert.
--- Spell
Syntax: cast 'sleep' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: Yes to mobs. No to players Cumulative: No Duration: Until the target is awakened or the spell wears off (duration dependant on caster's level). Type of Spell: Enchantment
A successful spellcast will cause the target to fall under a magical sleep. A target that is affected by this spell cannot wake himself up. Someone else must awaken him using the WAKE command.

Syntax: slookup <sn> Syntax: slookup <skill or spell> Syntax: slookup all
SLOOKUP shows you the internal 'sn' and skill or spell name for the given skill, spell, or 'sn'. The 'sn' is used for OSET and OSTAT. 'sn' is not used for player files; these operate with the actual skill and spell names.
SLOOKUP ALL shows this information for all skills and spells.

This spell slows the movement of the target, making it difficult for them to fight during battle. It will cancel the effects of the "haste" spell.

This spell causes a person afflicted by poison to feel its effects more slowly.

"Snailspeed" causes the target's maximum amount of moves to be reduced. The amount is dependant on the power of the caster.

Applied Skill Innate Ability
Sneak allows you to attempt to move silently from one place to another. A person who successfully sneaks will be able to travel without anyone noticing him entering or leaving an area. You cannot tell when you have successfully sneaked or not. There is no success or failure message.
The sneak skill must be toggled on or off, and takes up additional movement points when active.
The innate ability is always in effect.

SNOOP shows you a copy of all the input and output going to a character. The character must have an open channel. You may snoop more than one character at a time.
SNOOP yourself to cancel all outstanding snoops.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'soothe wound' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: No Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of Spell: Healing
This spell conjures up a magical force that bandages the target, healing small to moderate wounds instantly, with no signs that the original injury ever took place.

Sorcerers are spellcasters who have focused their lives on gaining power from the magical forces that surround them. They wield incredible offensive power with their magic, but their physical abilities are lacking. Sorcerers, like all magic-users, must rely on spellbooks to contain their accumulated knowledge. The spellbook is used when memorizing the spell, but once it has been cast, the knowledge of its casting disappears from the sorcerer's memory.
Important Attributes: Intelligence
Races: Drow Elf, Grey Elf, Flind, Githyanki, Half-Elf, Halfling, Human, Gnome, Orc, Rakshasa
Equipment: Sorcerers are spellcasters and are very limited in their use of weapons and armor. They have an unsurpassed ability to use magical objects such as staves, wands, and scrolls.
Innate Abilities: None

Reflexive Skill
This skill lets you recognize and identify magical spells when they are being cast by others.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'soul disturbance' <target> Area of effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: Yes Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of spell: Spirit
"Soul disturbance" causes the target's soul to be wracked with pain, doing considerable damage.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'soulshield' Area of Effect: Self Aggressive: No Cumulative: No Duration: Dependant on proficiency of the cater Type of Spell: Alteration
This spell creates an aura of aligned power around the caster which protects him against all melee attacks from attackers of the opposite alignment. He is harder to hit and attackers of the opposite alignment will take damage from the shield if they do hit.
The spell also provides protection against dispel good/evil spells and holy/unholy word.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'spark' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: Yes Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of Spell: Invokation
This spell concentrates all the energy and heat of a blazing fire into a single spark, which strikes a target with an amazing ferocity. The damage from this spell is significant and quite painful.

This command lets you change which language you are currently speaking to a new one by typing "speak <language>." Note that you cannot change if you are not proficient enough in the target language.
"Speak" alone shows a list of your language proficiencies, as well as your currently spoken language.

Unlike Basternae I, you do not need a spellbook object for memorizing spells. A caster is assumed to always have his spellbook with him, even after dying. This "virtual spellbook" only needs to have a spell inscribed in it once and then the caster will have it forever. His chances of casting the spell will go up as he gains in skill at the individual spells.

Help.Text:
Syntax: spells Syntax: slist
SPELLS will give a list of all the spells available to your class. If you are a mage who requires a spellbook, it will also indicate whether you have the spell in any spellbooks in your inventory or equipped.

Help.SeeAlso: cast, spell failure, spell circles, caster, magic

Spell
Syntax: cast 'spirit anguish' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: Yes Cumulative: No Duration: Dependent on proficiency of the caster Type of spell: Spiritual
"Spirit anguish" causes the target's spirit to undergo considerable anguish, causing unbearable pain.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'spirit armor' <target> Area of Effect: <target> Aggressive: No Cumulative: No Duration: Dependent on proficiency of the caster Type of spell: Spiritual
"Spirit armor" causes the target to be protected, lowering his armor class and protecting him from spells at higher caster levels. The amount the target is protected is based on the caster's proficiency.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'spirit jump' <target> Area of Effect: Self Aggressive: No Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of spell: Spiritual
"Spirit jump" causes the shaman to displace himself to the target's location. The target must be in the same zone as the caster, and there is no chance of the caster teleporting himself to a wrong location. The target must be introduced to the caster.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'spirit sight' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: No Cumulative: No Duration: Dependent on proficiency of the caster Type of Spell: Spiritual
"Spirit sight" allows the target to detect the auras of evil, good, and magic, much like the corresponding spells "detect evil/good/magic".

Spell
Syntax: cast 'spirit ward' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: No Cumulative: No Duration: Dependent on proficiency of the caster Type of Spell: Spiritual
"Spirit ward" protects the target from lower circle spells as well as magic in general.

SPLIT splits some coins between you and all the members of your group who are in the same room as you. It's customary to SPLIT the money after a kill. The split command does nothing when you are not in a group.

Help.SeeAlso: bash, bodyslam, trip, ranger skills, hunter skills
Help.Syntax: springleap <target> OR springleap (while engaged in battle)
Help.Text:
Applied skill:
Aggressive: Yes
Springleap is used by Rangers and Hunters to either knock down or knock their opponents off balance. Springleap must be done from a kneeling position. A missed springleap will leave the aggressor on the ground and susceptable to major damage. Sometimes the ranger or hunter will take the target down with them so they are both on the ground.
Size does matter! One can only springleap opponents of like or near the same size.

Syntax: sstime Syntax: sstime <value>/reboot
This Directorship command sets the time of shutdown or reboot with accompanying warnings.
Value is the number of minutes till reboot or shutdown. (1440 minutes/day)
Reboot will toggle between reboot or shutdown.
SSTIME without an argument shows the time at which the mud will reboot or shutdown.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'stamina' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, touch Aggressive: No Cumulative: N/A Duration: Instant Type of Spell: Alteration
This spell restores a small amount of energy back to the target, giving back some lost movement points. The amount of movement points restored is dependant on the level of the caster.
STAND will take a character back to the standing position. It is used when you have fallen, been knocked down, knelt, or are sitting/lying down.

Applied Skill
STEAL is used to take money or items from another creature without their knowledge or consent. The success of your theft is directly dependant on your amount of skill, the status of the target, how many people are in the same room, and so on.
Stealing from other players can only be done once you have reached level 35.
Innate Ability [Halflings]
Halflings are unable to control what they attempt to steal. Even something as minor as a pat on the back might cause a halfling to steal objects!

Spell
Syntax: cast 'stoneskin' <target> Area of Effect: Single target, In-Room Aggressive: No Cumulative: No Duration: Dependant on proficiency of the caster Type of Spell: Enchantment
This spell causes the target's skin to gain the toughness of solid stone, protecting him from most types of physical damage. Most weapons simply bounce off the target's skin, doing only cosmetic damage, but some critical hits can still penetrate the magical field and do normal damage.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'stonestrength' <target> Area of Effect: Singet target, Touch Aggressive: No Cumulative: No Duration: Dependant on proficiency of the caster Type of spell: Enchantment
Like the "strength" spell, this spell enhances the target's physical strength. However, this spell is a much more powerful version, which offers more benefits than the lesser spell.

Spell
Syntax: cast 'stornogs spheres' Area of Effect: Self only Aggressive: No Cumulative: No Duration: Dependant on proficiency of caster Type of Spell: Conjuration
This spell calls forth globes of magical energy to begin circling around the mage. These spheres dart in front of harmful spells cast at the mage, protecting him by nullifying the attack. The amount of spheres the mage can have up at any given time is dependant on the level of the caster.

The story of the world of ModernMUD 3 is a simple one, but that makes it no less tragic.
The world is shattered, effectively split in two between the surface world and that of the Underdark, a massive collections of caves and tunnels that runs underground. On the surface, the "good" aligned races make their homes, while the "evil" races either choose or are forced to live in the dangerous Underdark.
For all of recorded history, the good and evil races have been at war. Armies march forward to combat, one side wins and slays the other, then is destroyed itself by another army. It is a vicious cycle of warfare and neither side seems inclined to put a stop to it. The "good" races talk of peace, but it's a peace that would cost the lives of all unclean or unpure races of the dark. The evil races know only war, trained from birth to live in hostile environments. Horrible creatures make their homes in the Underdark, more than willing to kill any victims for food or sport, but it's just as likely a young evil will find himself dead from the knife of one of his kin.
It's the world of ModernMUD, where reflexes and fighting skills are constantly honed to perfection, where adventure waits around every corner, and death can lurk behind even the most friendly of faces. It's a world of combat and destruction, where fame and forture go to the aggressive and the meek get stomped into the ground.
Welcome home. Welcome to ModernMUD.

Attribute, Spell, Innate
Strength is a measure of raw, physical power, the ability to manipulate matter with muscles. It is the primary attribute for warrior classes, and has use for other classes as well. It affects how much you can carry, how heavy of a weapon you can wield, and so on.

Innate
Strength is also an innate ability of mountain dwarves. The innate ability works exactly like the spell effect, but it is not cumulative.

This spell will attempt to summon the named target if in the caster's zone. It is not possible to summon a creature of significantly greater level than the caster. In addition, many rooms and creatures are special and cannot be summoned under any circumstances.

Innate
Aggressive: no
This skill lets a paladin or anti-paladin call upon his diety for a mount. This skill can only be used three times per week and the type of mount that appears depends on your level and proficiency. You must be outdoors and level 10 or higher to try and summon a mount which will appear after a short period of time.
